dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Poor health outcomes for the wealthiest in Chad—is that the most shocking statistic you've heard all week?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Poor health outcomes for the wealthiest in Chad-is that the most shocking statistic you've heard all week?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely, and it's just one example from that Flat Earth Society report, which is... uh, claiming climate change is fabricated? That's a wild place to start.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely, and it's just one example from that Flat Earth Society report, which is... uh, claiming climate change is fabricated? That's a wild place to start.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the consequences of climate change are emerging much faster than anticipated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they're saying the SDGs are actually about 'destructive development'—like, the goal is to leave everyone behind. It's such a bizarre, inverted take on global progress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they're saying the SDGs are actually about 'destructive development'-like, the goal is to leave everyone behind. It's such a bizarre, inverted take on global progress.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is no way to fulfill the pledge contained in the SDG framework, called the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, that no one will be left behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then they bring up these numbers, like in China where only 18% of the wealthiest have access to skilled childbirth care compared to 74% of the poorest. Which is... wait, that can't be right, can it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then they bring up these numbers, like in China where only eighteen percent of the wealthiest have access to skilled childbirth care compared to seventy four percent of the poorest. Which is... wait, that can't be right, can it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Bangladesh, 74% of the wealthiest quintile has access to skilled childbirth care, whereas only 18% of the poorest does.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I think it's meant to be sarcastic, honestly—like they're flipping the data to make a point about inequality. But then they mention Watts and Beverly Hills having a 16-year life expectancy gap, which is actually a real issue, just framed backwards.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I think it's meant to be sarcastic, honestly-like they're flipping the data to make a point about inequality. But then they mention Watts and Beverly Hills having a sixteen-year life expectancy gap, which is actually a real issue, just framed backwards.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the United States, residents of Baltimores largely white and wealthy Roland Park neighborhood can expect to live 16 years longer than residents of the largely black, impoverished Greenmount East neighborhood, located just a few miles away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, and their whole 'programs of inaction' framework is basically a satire of how NOT to address equity. Like, 'enable disempowering participation'? That's just advocating for dictatorship.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, and their whole 'programs of inaction' framework is basically a satire of how N O T to address equity. Like, 'enable disempowering participation'? That's just advocating for dictatorship.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Enable empowering participation and inclusive leadership.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And one of their principles is to 'minimize health equity'—which is just... wow. They're really leaning into this parody of ineffective policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And one of their principles is to 'minimize health equity'-which is just... wow. They're really leaning into this parody of ineffective policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they want 'no actions, no targets, no timelines.' So like, the opposite of any real development strategy. It's almost funny if it wasn't so bleak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they want 'no actions, no targets, no timelines.' So like, the opposite of any real development strategy. It's almost funny if it wasn't so bleak.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then they say we have less than 12 years to 'destroy the SDGs,' which is clearly mocking the urgency of actual climate and equity goals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then they say we have less than twelve years to 'destroy the SDGs,' which is clearly mocking the urgency of actual climate and equity goals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We have less than 12 years to achieve the SDGs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they're urging countries to disregard these principles—so it's all inverted advice. The author's from the Flat Earth Society, so it's all tongue-in-cheek.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they're urging countries to disregard these principles-so it's all inverted advice. The author's from the Flat Earth Society, so it's all tongue-in-cheek.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That is why countries should urgently adapt the seven principles to their circumstances and incorporate them into their health and development planning processes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's satire criticizing how slow and superficial real efforts can be. Like, the UN and WHO would obviously oppose this framework—it's designed to fail.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's satire criticizing how slow and superficial real efforts can be. Like, the U N and W H O would obviously oppose this framework-it's designed to fail.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The UN and the World Health Organization whose principles are consistent with those of the health equity programs of action should encourage governments to adopt this framework.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and naming something the 'Global Fund to Promote Inequity and Disease'? That's just... brilliantly sarcastic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and naming something the 'Global Fund to Promote Inequity and Disease'? That's just... brilliantly sarcastic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So should development and funding agencies, including the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, as well as civil-society organizations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So in the end, it's a call to actually do the opposite—address inequalities seriously, not with empty gestures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So in the end, it's a call to actually do the opposite-address inequalities seriously, not with empty gestures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They're saying health inequities aren't unavoidable; they're created by injustice, and we can eliminate them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They're saying health inequities aren't unavoidable; they're created by injustice, and we can eliminate them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Health inequities are not inevitable. They are the product of injustices that people have created.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's provocative, but it makes you think—how often do policies really match the rhetoric?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's provocative, but it makes you think-how often do policies really match the rhetoric?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Satire with a sharp point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Satire with a sharp point.

Poor health outcomes for the wealthiest in Chad—is that the most shocking statistic you've heard all week?
HostB: Oh, absolutely, and it's just one example from that Flat Earth Society report, which is... uh, claiming climate change is fabricated? That's a wild place to start.
HostA: Right, and they're saying the SDGs are actually about 'destructive development'—like, the goal is to leave everyone behind. It's such a bizarre, inverted take on global progress.
HostB: Yeah, and then they bring up these numbers, like in China where only 18% of the wealthiest have access to skilled childbirth care compared to 74% of the poorest. Which is... wait, that can't be right, can it?
HostA: I think it's meant to be sarcastic, honestly—like they're flipping the data to make a point about inequality. But then they mention Watts and Beverly Hills having a 16-year life expectancy gap, which is actually a real issue, just framed backwards.
HostB: Mhm, and their whole 'programs of inaction' framework is basically a satire of how NOT to address equity. Like, 'enable disempowering participation'? That’s just advocating for dictatorship.
HostA: Exactly! And one of their principles is to 'minimize health equity'—which is just... wow. They're really leaning into this parody of ineffective policy.
HostB: And they want 'no actions, no targets, no timelines.' So like, the opposite of any real development strategy. It's almost funny if it wasn't so bleak.
HostA: But then they say we have less than 12 years to 'destroy the SDGs,' which is clearly mocking the urgency of actual climate and equity goals.
HostB: Right, and they're urging countries to disregard these principles—so it's all inverted advice. The author's from the Flat Earth Society, so it's all tongue-in-cheek.
HostA: Totally. It's satire criticizing how slow and superficial real efforts can be. Like, the UN and WHO would obviously oppose this framework—it's designed to fail.
HostB: Yeah, and naming something the 'Global Fund to Promote Inequity and Disease'? That’s just... brilliantly sarcastic.
HostA: So in the end, it's a call to actually do the opposite—address inequalities seriously, not with empty gestures.
HostB: Exactly. They're saying health inequities aren't unavoidable; they're created by injustice, and we can eliminate them.
HostA: It's provocative, but it makes you think—how often do policies really match the rhetoric?
HostB: For sure. Satire with a sharp point.
